alt_statements.statement: As someone who spends a lot of time online for music and entertainment, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be completely transparent about what data they collect, what they do with it, and to give us real, simple choices about opting out. Just because I’m using a “free” service doesn’t mean my privacy should be treated like a product they can sell without my informed consent. They should be held legally accountable when they misuse or are careless with our data, especially for vulnerable or low-income communities who don’t always have the time, resources, or education to fully understand the fine print. In a democracy, data shouldn’t become a tool to manipulate people’s views or exploit their personal struggles just to maximize profit.

As a conservative and a family man, I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat users’ data with the same care they’d want for their own children’s information—collecting only what is truly necessary and being completely transparent about how it’s used. They should never sell or share personal data in ways that could harm people’s privacy, security, or dignity, and there must be clear consequences when they abuse that trust. Especially for immigrants and people without strong legal protections, tech companies should not exploit our data just to make more profit, but respect our rights and our private lives.

As someone who works with sensitive financial information every day, I believe tech companies should be held to at least the same standard of rigor, transparency, and accountability that we apply in accounting and tax services. Users deserve clear, straightforward explanations—in plain language—about what data is collected, how it’s used, and with whom it’s shared, along with meaningful options to opt out of monetization that could compromise their privacy. Given my values around justice and equality, I also think companies have a responsibility to ensure data isn’t used in ways that reinforce discrimination or exploit vulnerable groups. Ultimately, respect for human dignity should weigh more than short-term profit in every data-driven decision.

I may not understand all the new technology, but I know that when people give you something personal, you must treat it with honesty and respect. Tech companies should clearly explain what they are taking, why they are taking it, and ask permission in a way ordinary people can understand, not just hide it in long papers. They should never use our information to trick us, divide families, or take advantage of the elderly or the poor just to make more money. If they cannot act responsibly on their own, then the government should set stricter rules to protect people’s privacy and dignity.

I think tech companies should have to tell us clearly what data they’re taking and exactly how they’re using it, in words kids and parents can actually understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share personal information—especially from kids—without getting real permission, and they should keep it super safe so hackers can’t get it. If they make money from our data, they should also give us easy ways to turn tracking off and delete what they’ve collected about us.

As a medical research scientist, I’m acutely aware of how sensitive data can be and how easily it can be misused, so I believe tech companies have an ethical obligation to treat user data more like protected health information than a free commodity. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, obtain informed and specific consent for how it’s used or monetized, minimize data collection to what’s genuinely necessary, and be held to strict accountability standards—legal and financial—when they fail. From both a scientific and Jewish ethical standpoint, respecting human dignity and preventing harm (pikuach nefesh) should come before profit, which means users must retain meaningful control over their data and the right to opt out without being penalized.

Tech companies make huge profits from our data, so they should be legally required to be transparent about what they collect, how they use it, and who they sell it to. As someone who cares about justice and the environment, I see data privacy as part of respecting people and communities, not just as a “terms of service” box to check. Users should have real control over their information, including easy ways to opt out and delete data, and there should be strict limits on targeting kids and vulnerable groups. If they abuse our trust, there should be serious consequences, not just small fines they treat as a cost of doing business.

I think if tech companies take our information, they should keep it super safe so no bad guys can get it. They should tell our parents exactly what they’re doing with it and ask first, especially for kids, and never use it to trick people into buying stuff they don’t need.

As someone who works in retail and deals with customers every day, I think tech companies should be held to at least the same standard of honesty and respect we owe shoppers in a grocery store. They should clearly explain what data they’re taking, how they’re using it, and give people real choices to opt out without losing basic access to services. I’m fine with companies making money, but not by sneaking around people’s privacy—there ought to be strong regulations, like we have for food safety, to protect folks’ personal information from abuse or exploitation.

As someone who’s spent his career protecting people and enforcing the law, I believe tech companies should treat user data like evidence in a chain of custody: clearly documented, tightly controlled, and never used beyond what people knowingly agreed to. They should be legally required to be transparent about what they collect, how they profit from it, and to give users real options to opt out. If a government agency mishandled personal information there’d be consequences, and big tech shouldn’t be playing by looser rules just because they move fast and wear hoodies instead of uniforms.

I think tech companies should have to be super clear about what data they collect and exactly how they use it, in words that kids and regular people can actually understand. If they’re making money off our info, we should have a real choice to say no, and they shouldn’t be allowed to secretly track us or sell our data without permission. Since a lot of us use apps for school, games, and talking with friends, they should have extra rules to protect kids and never use our data in ways that could embarrass us or put us in danger.

As someone who has spent a lifetime organizing in my community and fighting for dignity and fairness, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat our personal data with the same respect they’d want for their own families. They should collect only what is truly necessary, be completely transparent about how it’s used and who profits, and give people real power to say no without losing access to essential services. When companies make billions off our information, they owe us strong privacy protections, independent oversight, and clear accountability when they abuse our trust.

As someone who spent a career in business and believes in free markets, I still think tech companies have a clear responsibility to be honest and straightforward about what data they collect and how they profit from it. Users should have simple, understandable choices about their privacy, not pages of fine print no one can reasonably be expected to read. If a company mishandles or sells data in ways it didn’t clearly disclose, there ought to be real consequences—legal and financial—just like in any other regulated industry such as banking. Respecting people’s privacy isn’t anti-business; it’s part of earning and keeping the public’s trust.

Tech companies shouldn’t get to treat our personal data like a free-for-all just because we clicked “I agree” on a 20-page terms sheet. At minimum, they should be brutally clear about what they’re collecting, give us real options to opt out of tracking and targeted ads, and face serious penalties if they sell or misuse our info. People like me work hard for what little privacy we still have, and it shouldn’t be something corporations can quietly strip away for profit.

I may not be a tech expert, but I know enough to say that if a company is making money off people’s personal information, they’ve got a moral duty to be honest and careful about it. Tech companies should clearly explain what they collect, get real permission instead of burying it in fine print, and never sell or share data in ways that put people or families at risk. They ought to be held accountable, just like any other business, and remember there’s a human being behind every data point—someone who deserves privacy, dignity, and respect.

I may not work in tech, but I know what responsibility looks like from running a kitchen—people trust you with their food, and you don’t cut corners. Tech companies ought to be upfront and plainspoken about what data they’re taking, how they’re using it, and give folks a real choice to opt out, not hide it in fine print. I don’t mind companies making money, but they shouldn’t be selling or sharing personal information without clear consent, and there ought to be strict penalties when they misuse people’s data. Just like health codes keep restaurants honest, we need strong laws to keep tech companies accountable.

I think tech companies should have to ask very clearly before they use our information, especially for kids, and explain it in words we can actually understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share our data just to make money if it could hurt us or make us feel unsafe, and they should keep our information super protected, like locking it in a strong safe.

As someone who spent a career making sure legal services complied with regulations, I believe tech companies should be held to clear, enforceable standards when collecting and monetizing user data. People deserve to know exactly what is being collected, how it’s used, and to have a simple, meaningful way to opt out—no buried fine print. Data practices should be treated a bit like fiduciary duties: companies ought to act in the best interests of users, not just their shareholders, and face real penalties when they abuse that trust.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the decades, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat people’s data like something sacred, not just a product to be exploited. They should be required to explain in plain language what they’re collecting, get clear permission before using or selling it, and give users real control over what happens to their information. With so much of life happening online now, especially for older folks like me who rely on these services, we need strong privacy protections enforced by law, not just corporate promises.

As someone who works in a regulated industry and has to answer to owners and tenants, I think tech companies should be held to similar standards of transparency and accountability when it comes to user data. If they’re going to collect and profit from our information, they should clearly explain what they’re taking, how it’s used, and give us real control over opting in or out—not bury it in fine print. I’m not against innovation or businesses making money, but there should be strict privacy protections and strong consequences when companies abuse people’s trust.

If these big tech companies are going to track what we do and make money off it, they ought to be straight with us about exactly what they’re taking and how they’re using it, in plain English, not a 20‑page fine print. They should collect only what they really need to provide the service, get our clear permission first, and give us a simple way to say no and delete our information. I don’t trust any corporation to “do the right thing” on its own, so there should be strong laws and penalties to keep them honest, just like we regulate other industries that affect people’s lives.

I think tech companies should be honest and clear about what they’re doing with our data, especially for kids and teens who might not really understand all the fine print. If they’re making money off our information, they should protect it like it’s something valuable and not sell or share it in ways that could hurt us or embarrass us later. They should also give us simple choices to control what they collect, instead of hiding everything in long, confusing privacy policies.

As someone who runs her own business and relies on financial records every day, I believe tech companies have a serious duty to be transparent, secure, and conservative in how they collect and use people’s data. Users should clearly know what’s being gathered, why, and how it’ll be monetized, and companies should be legally accountable if they misuse or fail to protect that information. I’m not against innovation or profit, but personal data should never be treated like a free-for-all commodity—there must be firm boundaries and respect for individual privacy.

If tech companies are going to collect and sell our data, they should at least be straight up about what they’re taking and give us real control over it, not just a bunch of confusing settings no one understands. People my age basically live online, so it feels messed up that our info can be traded around without us really knowing who has it or what they’re doing with it. I think there should be clear limits on how data can be used, especially for ads and tracking, and strong laws to punish companies that lie, leak data, or put profit over people’s privacy.

As someone who works in community outreach and really values trust and fairness, I think tech companies should treat user data like a loan from the public, not a resource they own outright. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, minimize it to only what’s necessary, get meaningful consent, and give people real control over how their data is used and monetized. If they profit from that data, there should be strict regulations, independent audits, and serious penalties when companies abuse people’s privacy or use data in ways that harm vulnerable communities.

Tech companies should treat people’s data with the same care and respect they’d want for their own families, always being honest about what they collect and how they use it. They shouldn’t use our information to take advantage of us, especially people who don’t fully understand the technology or language, and they must make it easy to say no. If they make money from our data, we deserve strong privacy protections and, when possible, a fair share of the benefit.

As a software developer, I think tech companies have a strict responsibility to collect only the data they truly need, explain clearly what they’re doing with it, and give users simple, meaningful control over how their information is used or sold. Coming from Europe and seeing how strong data protection frameworks like the GDPR work, I believe similar standards should be the norm everywhere: privacy by design, strict limits on data sharing, and serious penalties when companies abuse user trust.

As someone who’s spent a career protecting information systems, I think tech companies have a strict responsibility to collect only the data they truly need, secure it rigorously, and explain in plain language how it will be used and monetized. If they’re going to profit from users’ data, there should be clear, opt-in consent and strong legal accountability when that trust is broken. Data practices shouldn’t just meet the bare legal minimum; they should reflect basic respect for people’s privacy and dignity.

Tech companies ought to treat people’s data like something they’re borrowing, not something they own. They should be crystal clear about what they’re collecting, how they’re using it, and give users a simple way to say no, without punishing them for it. If they profit from our information, they should be held accountable when they misuse it or fail to protect it, just like any other business that mishandles customers’ property.

At my age, I’ve seen enough to know that when companies say “trust us,” you’d better read the fine print, especially with something as personal as our data. Tech companies should be required to explain in plain language what they’re collecting, get real consent before selling or sharing it, and face serious penalties when they abuse that trust. No one’s information—whether it’s a young person’s or an old widow like me—should be treated like a free-for-all just to make a profit. If they’re going to make money off our lives, they ought to be held to the same ethical standards I follow with my clients: honesty, respect, and no hidden surprises.

Tech companies shouldn’t be treating people’s personal information like a free-for-all just because we clicked “I agree” on some 20-page notice no one can understand. If they’re going to collect and profit from our data, they ought to be upfront in plain English about what they’re taking, get real permission, protect it like Fort Knox, and be held accountable when they mess up. I worked hard all my life and expect folks to be honest in business—big tech shouldn’t be any different.

As someone who works with measurements and records every day, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data with the same precision and respect I’m expected to show at my job. They should be fully transparent about what they collect, get clear consent before monetizing anything, and give people real control over how their information is used. Profit shouldn’t come before basic privacy rights, and there ought to be strong regulations to keep companies from abusing the trust people place in their platforms.

If tech companies are going to collect our data and make money off it, they should at least be totally transparent about what they’re taking and give us real, easy-to-use options to control it. Nobody reads 50-page terms of service, so they need clear, simple explanations and hard limits on selling or sharing data without explicit consent. I’m fine with companies using data to improve apps or recommend stuff, but selling out our privacy to advertisers or governments without us knowing is messed up and should be illegal.

As someone who sees every day how deeply personal information—like medical records—can affect a person’s dignity and safety, I believe tech companies have a solemn responsibility to treat user data with the same level of confidentiality and respect we owe patients. They should collect only what is truly necessary, be radically transparent about how it’s used and monetized, and give people meaningful control over their own information. Profit can never justify practices that manipulate, exploit, or endanger users, especially the most vulnerable. From both a humanitarian and a Catholic ethical perspective, the human person must come before the algorithm and the balance sheet.

Working in local government, I’m used to being held accountable for how we use residents’ information, and I think tech companies should be held to at least the same standard. They ought to collect only the data that’s truly necessary, explain in plain language how it will be used and monetized, and give people real choices about opting in or out. If they profit from our data, there should be strong safeguards, independent oversight, and consequences when they break the public’s trust.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how sensitive personal information can be, I think tech companies should be held to strict, healthcare-level standards when they collect and monetize user data—clear consent, minimal necessary data, and real transparency about how it’s used. Data shouldn’t be treated as a free-for-all commodity; it should be handled as part of a broader social contract, where user privacy, mental health, and community well-being come before ad revenue.

As someone who works with data and technology every day, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data with the same rigor and ethics we apply to scientific research: informed consent, transparency, and clear limits on how data is used. They should be required to explain in plain language what they collect, why they collect it, how it’s monetized, and give users real control over opting out. Given the power imbalances in the digital economy, I also believe strong regulation is necessary to prevent exploitation, algorithmic discrimination, and surveillance creep, especially for marginalized or non-citizen communities.

When I think of tech companies poring over the intimate details of our lives, I’m reminded of how carefully one must handle an old manuscript: with restraint, respect, and an awareness that its contents are not yours to exploit. Companies should be legally required to collect only what is truly necessary, explain in plain language how data will be used, and give people real power to opt out of tracking and sale. Data about our habits, beliefs, and relationships is not just a commodity; it’s an extension of our dignity, and it ought to be protected by strong public oversight and enforceable penalties for abuse.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over 65 years and worked in a people-focused role, I believe tech companies have a duty to treat our data with the same care a clinic treats our medical records: clear consent, strict limits on sharing, and transparency about who profits and how. They shouldn’t be allowed to quietly track and monetize people—especially vulnerable folks, like those of us with disabilities—without plain-language explanations and real options to opt out. If they make money off our information, they should also be held accountable when that data is misused or leads to discrimination, and there ought to be strong laws backing that up.

As someone who’s worked hard all my life and doesn’t have much margin for error, I think tech companies have a moral duty to be honest and straightforward about what they’re doing with our data—no sneaky fine print. If they’re going to make money off our information, they should need our clear permission, keep it secure like they would their own, and be held accountable when they misuse it. Privacy is part of basic dignity, and big companies shouldn’t be allowed to trample that just because they have the power and the technology.

As someone who works in education and cares about my community, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like they would a student’s confidential file: collect only what’s truly necessary, protect it rigorously, and be fully transparent about how it’s used and monetized. Users should have clear, simple options to opt out of data sharing and to delete their information, and there should be strong legal consequences when companies misuse or sell data in ways people didn’t knowingly agree to.

As someone who works with customers every day, I feel strongly that tech companies should treat user data with the same respect I’m expected to show the people I serve—clear communication, honest choices, and no hidden tricks. They should be required to explain in plain English what they’re collecting, why they’re collecting it, and exactly how it’s being sold or shared, and users should have an easy way to opt out without being punished. I support stronger regulations to keep corporations from exploiting people’s information for profit, because privacy and dignity shouldn’t be things you have to give up just to use basic technology.

I think tech companies should have to ask really clearly before they take our data, and explain it in words kids and parents can actually understand. They should also give families simple ways to turn data collection off and check what’s already been collected.

As someone who spent her life teaching young people and now volunteers at the library, I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat user data like a public trust, not a gold mine to be secretly exploited. They should clearly explain what they’re collecting in plain English, get real consent instead of hiding behind fine print, and never sell or share information in ways that could harm people or their communities. I also think they ought to be legally required to minimize what they collect, protect it strongly, and be fully transparent about how they profit from it.

Tech companies make a lot of money off our data, so they should be legally required to be upfront, specific, and honest about what they collect and how they use it, in plain language anyone can understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share sensitive data—like health, location, or financial info—without explicit, opt‑in consent, and users should have a real right to see, correct, and delete their data. I’d also support stronger government regulation and independent audits to keep them accountable, because “trust us” isn’t enough when your entire life is basically being tracked.

If these big tech companies are going to make money off our data, they ought to be straight with us about what they’re taking and how they’re using it, in plain English, not legal mumbo-jumbo. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share anything beyond what’s needed to run the service unless we clearly say yes, and there should be real consequences when they misuse or leak people’s information. I work hard for my paycheck and my privacy should be treated with the same respect—government’s job is to set firm rules and then make sure these companies actually follow them.

As someone who manages a business and works with customer data every day, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data the way a good retailer treats customer trust: as something you safeguard first, and only leverage with clear, informed consent. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with, and they should give people simple, real choices to opt out of invasive tracking without being penalized. In a democracy, especially one I chose by becoming a citizen, data shouldn’t become a tool for manipulation or discrimination, so strong internal ethics and external regulation both matter. Ultimately, profit can never justify practices that undermine people’s dignity, privacy, or ability to participate freely in society.

Tech companies shouldn’t be able to just scoop up every bit of our personal info and sell it off without us knowing exactly what’s happening and having a real choice in the matter. I work hard for a living and expect to be treated honestly, so if they’re making money off my data, there ought to be clear rules, real accountability, and serious penalties when they misuse it. At the same time, we shouldn’t strangle innovation with pointless red tape, but basic privacy, transparency, and respect for families and kids online ought to be non‑negotiable.

Tech companies should treat our personal data with the same care and honesty I expect from any business I deal with face-to-face—clear permission, no fine-print tricks, and no selling more than we agreed to. I don’t mind them using data to improve services or show relevant products, but they should be legally required to protect it from hackers, be upfront about exactly what they collect and why, and give us simple options to opt out.

As someone who works in public education and sees every day how vital trust is to any community, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data with the same care we owe our students and families: clear consent, strict limits on use, and real accountability when they get it wrong. Data that’s collected should be the minimum necessary, transparently explained, and never used in ways that harm people’s opportunities, health, or privacy—especially for kids and vulnerable communities. If companies profit from our information, they should also be required to invest in safeguards, independent oversight, and public education so people truly understand what they’re agreeing to.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see technology transform from rotary phones to smartphones, I believe tech companies have a serious duty to treat our personal data with the same respect a museum owes a priceless painting—no touching, no selling, no sharing without clear, informed consent. They should be fully transparent about how data is collected and monetized, and give users simple, real choices, not pages of legalese. No one, especially older folks and people with disabilities, should be exploited just because it’s profitable to track our every move online. If companies profit from our data, there should be strict accountability, strong regulation, and real penalties when they cross the line.

As someone who works hard for a living, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be straight with people about what data they collect and how they’re making money off it. They shouldn’t be selling or sharing personal information without clear, honest consent, and there ought to be real consequences when they misuse it. I’m not against businesses making a profit, but they should respect individual privacy and basic dignity while they do it.

As someone who’s family-oriented, conservative, and active online for school, I think tech companies have a serious moral responsibility to treat user data like someone’s personal property, not just a product. I don’t think government should micromanage everything, but there should be strong laws and real penalties when companies lie, misuse data, or fail to protect it from hackers. At minimum, people deserve simple tools to see, control, and delete the information that’s being used to make money off of them.

Tech companies that treat our personal data as a commodity without real consent are, to borrow from Orwell, playing both Big Brother and the Ministry of Truth. As someone who works with words for a living, I’m especially wary of opaque privacy policies that hide predatory practices behind legalese—they should be held legally accountable when they mislead or exploit users. Data rights should be understood as civil rights, not just terms-of-service footnotes.

Tech companies should only collect the data they truly need to run their services and be completely honest and simple about what they’re doing with it, so regular people like me can actually understand. As a conservative and a mother, I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to be honest and transparent about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with—especially when it comes to children. They should need clear permission before monetizing our information, make it easy to opt out, and be held accountable if they misuse or fail to protect people’s data.

As someone who loves new technology but also lives on a tight income and deals with a disability, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and fair when they collect and monetize our data. If these companies profit from our information, they should be held to strict standards and be accountable when they violate our trust.

Tech companies should be free to innovate and profit from data, but only if they’re upfront and honest about what they’re collecting and give people a real choice in the matter. As someone who values individual freedom and personal responsibility, I think users should clearly own their data and be able to opt out easily, without being punished with a worse service. Companies that abuse trust or quietly sell sensitive information should face real consequences, because consent isn’t meaningful if it’s buried in legalese no one can understand.

I think tech companies should treat our data kind of like a library treats books—carefully, respectfully, and never using it without clear permission. They should explain in simple language what they collect, why they collect it, and how they make money from it, so even kids my age can understand. I also believe they shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share personal information that could embarrass, manipulate, or harm people, especially younger users.

I think tech companies should have to ask really clearly before they take our data, and explain it in words kids and parents can understand, not super confusing stuff. If they’re gonna make money from our info, they should keep it super safe, not sell way more than they need, and let our parents say no or delete it if they want.

My parents say that when companies take people’s information, they should be honest about what they’re doing and protect it like they’d protect a little kid. As someone who spends a lot of time online for school, community projects, and cooking ideas, I think tech companies should treat our data like something they’re borrowing, not something they own. If they profit from our data, they should be transparent about it and be held accountable when they’re careless or dishonest.

As someone who works with sensitive financial information, I believe tech companies have a serious duty to treat user data with the same care we apply to clients’ money: collect only what’s truly necessary, be fully transparent about how it’s used, and give people meaningful control over it. Monetizing data shouldn’t come at the expense of privacy or fairness, so strong safeguards, clear consent, and accountability for misuse are essential, ideally backed by robust regulation.

Tech companies have a serious responsibility to be honest and straightforward about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they sell it to—no fine-print games. If they’re going to profit off our information, they should need our clear consent, protect that data like it’s gold, and face real legal consequences when they misuse it. I don’t want big tech acting like an unaccountable government; they should be tightly regulated and kept in their lane.

I’m little, so I don’t really understand all the computer stuff, but I know it’s not okay when people take things from me without asking. They should keep kids especially safe and never sell or share our personal things in ways that could hurt us or make us feel scared or watched.

As someone who believes in community and looking out for one another, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be completely honest and clear about how they collect and sell our data, especially for people like me who don’t always follow all the technical details. If they’re making money off our information, they should be held to strict rules about privacy, security, and how long they keep that data, and they should face real consequences if they abuse our trust. No one should have to trade away their dignity or safety just to use basic online services.

As someone who builds software for a living, I think tech companies have a responsibility to collect only the data they actually need, explain clearly how it’s used, and give users real control over what’s shared and monetized. Data shouldn’t be treated as an unlimited resource to exploit, but as something entrusted to us that can materially affect people’s lives, opportunities, and even their safety. Especially for immigrants and other vulnerable groups, opaque data practices can reinforce power imbalances, so strong privacy protections and strict limits on data sharing should be the default, not an optional feature.

I think tech companies should ask people in simple words before they take our information, and explain what they’re doing like how a teacher explains a new rule in class. They shouldn’t sell or share our data in sneaky ways, and they need extra rules to keep kids’ information super safe, like putting a strong lock on a diary so no one can peek without permission.

If tech companies are going to collect our data, they should be completely honest about what they’re taking, how they’re using it, and give us real choices to say no without losing basic access. Since a lot of us grew up online and don’t always read the fine print, I think they have a responsibility to protect our privacy by default, not exploit it for profit. They should be required to secure our info, avoid selling super detailed profiles to shady third parties, and face serious consequences if they misuse people’s data.

As someone who works in finance for a telecom company and is constantly around data and tech, I think companies have a responsibility to treat user data like a privilege, not an entitlement. At minimum, that means clear, plain-language disclosures, strict limits on what’s collected, and no selling or sharing without truly informed, opt-in consent. Data should be anonymized by default, subject to independent audits, and protected with the same rigor we’d apply to sensitive financial information. If a business model can’t survive without exploiting people’s privacy, then it’s the model—not the regulations—that needs to change.

As someone who has spent a lifetime teaching and thinking critically about institutions and power, I believe tech companies have a moral and civic responsibility to treat user data with the same care we demand for medical or financial records. At minimum, they should disclose clearly—in plain language—what they collect, how they profit from it, and give people real, accessible choices to opt in or out. Given the long history of exploitation in communities like mine, they must also be held legally accountable for discriminatory uses of data, such as biased algorithms in housing, employment, or policing. Profit can never justify practices that undermine human dignity, privacy, or democratic participation.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the years, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat our data like something precious, not just something to be bought and sold. They should be completely transparent about what they collect, get clear consent in plain language, and give people real control over what’s shared and with whom. I’m especially concerned about how data can be misused against vulnerable people—like seniors, disabled folks, and Black communities—so there need to be strong rules to prevent discrimination, scams, and surveillance. If they profit from our information, they should also be held legally accountable when that information is abused or leaked.

As someone who spends my days teaching teenagers and worrying about what follows them online, I believe tech companies have a serious ethical responsibility to treat user data like a public trust, not a gold mine. At a minimum, they should collect only what’s necessary, explain clearly and honestly how it’s used, and give people real, easy-to-use control over their information. Monetizing data without informed consent—especially from young people—is exploitative, and we need stronger regulation to keep profit motives from overriding basic rights to privacy and dignity.

Tech companies that collect and monetize user data have a responsibility to treat that data like a public trust, not a private gold mine. At a minimum, they should provide plain-language explanations of what they’re collecting, secure it to medical-grade standards, and give users real control over how it’s used—including an easy opt-out from data sales. Given how sensitive health and personal information can be, there should also be strong, enforceable regulations and independent oversight so protections don’t depend on corporate goodwill.

If these big tech companies are going to make money off our data, they should at least be honest about it and make it simple enough for someone like me to understand what I’m agreeing to. They ought to get clear permission, give people real control to opt out, and be held legally responsible if they misuse information or let it get stolen. No one should have to trade away their privacy just to use basic services or stay in touch with family online.

As someone who’s spent a career protecting people and evidence, I believe tech companies should treat user data with the same seriousness we treat sensitive case files: collected narrowly, secured rigorously, and never misused. They ought to be fully transparent about what they gather and how they profit from it, and users should have clear, simple options to opt out. When that data can affect a person’s safety, reputation, or livelihood, profit should never come before privacy and accountability.

As someone who works hard every day to support my family, I think tech companies should be straight-up and honest about what they’re doing with our data, and get real consent instead of hiding things in fine print. If they’re making money off our information, they should protect it like it’s their own, and some of that profit should go back into the communities they’re taking it from—through better services, privacy protections, or even direct benefits.

As someone who works in a profit-driven industry, I understand the need for businesses to use data to stay competitive, but tech companies have a moral responsibility not to cross certain lines. They should be fully transparent about what they collect, get explicit consent, and never sell or share personally identifiable information without clear permission. There also needs to be serious accountability—strong security, tough penalties for misuse, and no manipulating people’s behavior in ways they don’t understand. Making money is fine, but not at the expense of people’s privacy, dignity, and basic trust.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit off our data, they should have to spell out in plain English exactly what they’re taking, what they’re doing with it, and give us a real choice to opt out. As someone who works for a private company and values personal responsibility and privacy, I think tech companies have a duty to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with—no fine-print tricks. From my perspective, if they’re making a profit off people’s data, there should be clear limits and accountability, not just “trust us” from big corporations.
